From Proto-Indo-European *key-d-, a dental extension of the root Proto-Indo-European *key- (â€œto move, to impelâ€). Cognate with Ancient Greek ÎºÎ¹Î½Î­Ï‰ (kinÃ©Å, â€œto set in motion, to arouseâ€), Latin cieÅ (â€œto set in motion, to summonâ€), Sanskrit à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¤à¥‡ (cyavate, â€œto come forth, to fall downâ€), Albanian qoj (â€œto wake upâ€). Perhaps the original notion was "to summon", i.e. "to order someone to come" (cf. the parallel usage of English cite (â€œto summon (someone)â€), from the cognate Latin root).
